description: Fisheries and Oceans Canada (DFO) is currently involved in research programs that investigates the diets, trophic status, and food web structure of marine mammals, Arctic fish, benthic invertebrates, and zooplankton. In collaboration with the University of Manitoba, biological samples have been collected from the Western and Southeastern Hudson Bay (Churchill, James Bay and Belcher Islands) to determine horizontal and vertical trophic structure from invertebrates (benthos and zooplankton) to fish and marine mammals to determine energy flow within this system. Using stable isotope analysis (d13C, d 15N and d 34S) of numerous species groups species groups (zooplankton, benthos, fishes, and marine mammals), our objectives are to: (1) estimate the trophic structure of these systems. In addition, d13C and d34S analysis across the food web allows the ability to (2) quantify horizontal energy flow (freshwater versus marine energy, pelagic versus benthic energy) throughout these ecosystems. As well, using d34S in a food web perspective has not been wide applied in the Arctic. En collaboration avec l'établissement universitaire du Manitoba, des échantillons biologiques ont été prélevés dans l'ouest et le sud-est de la baie d'Hudson (Churchill, baie James et îles Belcher) afin de déterminer la structure trophique horizontale et verticale des invertébrés (benthos et zooplancton) aux poissons et aux mammifères marins, puis connaître le transfert d'énergie au sein de ce système. En analysant les isotopes stables (d13C, d 15N and d 34S) de nombreux groupes spécifiques (zooplancton, benthos, poissons et mammifères marins), nos objectifs sont (1) d'évaluer la structure trophique de ces systèmes et, grâce à l'analyse du d13C et du d34S dans l'ensemble du réseau trophique, (2) de quantifier le transfert d'énergie horizontal (énergie de l'eau douce par rapport à l'énergie marine, énergie pélagique par rapport à l'énergie benthique) dans l'ensemble de ces écosystèmes. full_summary:
# **Title**
Stable Isotope Analysis of Food Web Samples from Hudson Bay

# **Reference Number**
cb-413-65557866

# **Announcement Details**
**Announcement Date**: February 20, 2024
**Closing Date**: March 19, 2024, at 13:00:00
**Expected Contract Start Date**: April 1, 2024
**Expected Contract End Date**: March 20, 2025

# **Notice Type**
This is a Request for Proposal (RFP) document.

# **Description**
Fisheries and Oceans Canada (DFO) invites proposals from qualified contractors to conduct stable isotope analysis of food web samples from Hudson Bay. The selected contractor will work in collaboration with the University of Manitoba to:

1. Determine the trophic structure of marine mammals, Arctic fish, benthic invertebrates, and zooplankton.
2. Quantify horizontal energy flow within the ecosystems, including freshwater and marine energy, and pelagic and benthic energy.

# **Scope of Work**
The scope of work includes:

* Collection of biological samples from Western and Southeastern Hudson Bay
* Stable isotope analysis (d13C, d15N, and d34S) of numerous species groups, including zooplankton, benthos, fishes, and marine mammals
* Identification of horizontal energy flow and trophic structure within the ecosystems

# **Evaluation Criteria**
Proposals will be evaluated based on the following criteria:

* Technical Merit: Demonstrated expertise and experience in stable isotope analysis and food web ecology
* Price: Fair and reasonable price for the services offered

# **Eligibility**
The contractor must be registered in the Supplier to the Public Services (TPS) database to be eligible to bid.

# **Contact Information**
For further information and to obtain a copy of the RFP document, please contact:
Terri Jones
Email: [terri.jones@dfo-mpo.gc.ca](mailto:terri.jones@dfo-mpo.gc.ca)
Phone: (506) 461-3743
Address: 301 Bishop Drive, Fredericton, NB, E3C 2M6, Canada

# **Attachments**
The RFP document is available in English and French. Please access the below links to download the document:

English: https://canadabuys.canada.ca/sites/default/files/webform/tender_notice/32402/300051
